Fig 8 Highly efficient MnOx catalysts derived from Mn-MOFs for chlorobenzene oxidation: The influence of MOFs precursors, oxidant and doping of Ce metal Tingting Jiang Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Xi Wang Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Junjie Zhang Resources Yuliang Mai Formal analysis Jiazhi Chen Supervision ⁎ Institute of Chemical Engineering, Guangdong Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou 510665, China Institute of Chemical Engineering Guangdong Academy of Sciences Guangzhou 510665 China Institute of Chemical Engineering, Guangdong Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou 510665, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. In this research, we introduce a simple, effective, and eco-friendly approach for preparing MnOx materials with a hierarchical porous structure and apply it to the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene. In this method, different Mn-based MOFs are used as templates, and MnOx materials with various morphologies and structures are prepared through an alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method. Different Mn-MOF precursors, oxidants and doping of different metals have a considerable influence on the structural morphology of the obtained MnOx materials. Through adjusting the structural morphology, it is conducive to transfer, diffusion and enrichment of chlorobenzene during the reaction process, and improving the reaction activity. MnO2-74 catalyst derived from Mn-MOF-74 in the presence of H2O2 showed the best catalytic activity (T90 = 174 °C). The exceptional catalytic efficiency is attributed to its large specific surface area, mesoporous structure, better low-temperature reducibility, sufficient acidic sites, and enhanced oxygen activation ability. The primary cause of the decrease in catalytic activity is the existence of surface carbon and inorganic chlorine on the catalyst. This green, efficient, and economical preparation method introduces a novel strategy for the traditional derivatization of MOFs to prepare metal oxide materials for the catalytic oxidation of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic oxidation Chlorobenzene Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Manganese oxide Alkaline hydrolysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) serve as primary sources to air pollution and important precursors to PM2.5 and ozone formation, which can further contribute to secondary pollutants such as photochemical smog [1]. VOCs encompass a wide range of compounds such as non-methane hydrocarbons, oxygenated organic compounds, chlorinated organic compounds, nitrogen-containing and sulfur-containing organic compounds. Chlorinated VOCs (CVOCs) are difficult to biodegrade, tend to accumulate in organisms, and have strong carcinogenic, teratogenic, and mutagenic effects [2]. Therefore, controlling the emission of CVOCs has become a key focus in VOCs management. Currently, the main technologies for CVOCs control include incineration, biological methods, adsorption, ultraviolet photolysis, and catalytic oxidation [3–6]. Among them, catalytic oxidation is widely used for CVOCs elimination [7–10]. However, incomplete combustion of CVOCs in practical applications can lead to the generation of chlorinated by-products and dioxins, which pose risks to the ecosystem and human well-being. Therefore, the design of catalysts featuring elevated activity, selectivity, and stability for low-temperature catalytic oxidation of CVOCs is of great significance [11,12]. So far, transition metal oxides [13,14], supported noble metal catalysts [15,16], and zeolites [17,18] have been applied in the catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. Among them, the catalytic performance of zeolites is mainly determined by their acidic sites, but they are prone to carbon deposition, leading to deactivation [19]. Although supported noble metal catalysts can attain remarkable catalytic activity under lower temperatures, the formation of polychlorinated by-products can lead to rapid catalyst deactivation, and their low reserves and high cost limit their large-scale application [20]. In contrast, catalysts based on transition metal oxide present distinct benefits including low cost, robust thermal durability, and resistance to chlorine poisoning [21]. Many transition metal oxide catalysts, including but not limited to MnOx [11], CeO2 [22], Co3O4 [23], Fe2O3 [24], and V2O5 [25], have been reported for their application in catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. Among them, manganese oxide exhibits excellent catalytic activity due to its multivalent state and unique electronic structure, which promote the generation and flow of active oxygen. For a long time, traditional techniques like sol-gel, co-precipitation, and hydrothermal methodologies have been employed to prepare manganese oxides [26–28]. In recent years, the template pyrolysis of MOFs has been employed as a novel preparation method to synthesize structurally unique manganese oxides or composite materials of manganese oxides and carbon [29]. The manganese oxides prepared by this method can inherit the abundant pore structure of MOFs while possessing controllable morphologies, making them highly promising for catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. For example, Mn-MOF-74, synthesized from manganese and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, is a typical MOF with excellent chemical stability. Our previous studies have shown that [30] rod-shaped MnOx catalysts prepared using Mn-MOF-74 as a sacrificial template exhibit outstanding activity in the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene at low concentrations, thanks to the substantial presence of active oxygen on the catalyst surface and the elevated Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio. In addition, Chen et al. [31] compared the catalytic activity of MnCeOx catalysts obtained by various preparation methodologies (co-precipitation, sol-gel, and MOFs pyrolysis) for the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene. They found that MnCeOx catalysts derived from MnCe-BDC exhibited rich microporous structures, higher lattice oxygen proportions, and better surface reducibility, resulting in optimal catalytic activity. In such methods, the pyrolysis temperature has a significant influence on the catalyst's activity. Zhang et al. [32] conducted a comparative analysis of the activity of catalysts prepared using MnCe-BTC as a sacrificial template at different pyrolysis temperatures and found that the catalyst prepared at 300 °C demonstrated the highest catalytic efficiency. Although the MOFs pyrolysis method has advantages over traditional methods in controlling catalyst morphology and increasing surface area, it still suffers from low yield, high energy consumption, and secondary pollution [33]. Moreover, at high pyrolysis temperatures, it is difficult to effectively control structure collapse and particle aggregation, resulting in the inability to finely tune the desired nanoscale structures. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop an eco-friendly and efficient method that can achieve high-throughput synthesis of metal oxides under mild conditions while allowing precise control of morphology and microstructure. In this research, we introduce a simple and efficient approach for the high-throughput synthesis of MnOx materials with controlled morphology and microstructure. Different Mn-based MOFs were used as templates, and through alkaline hydrolysis in the presence of an oxidant, MnOx materials with various morphologies and structures were in-situ obtained. This alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method not only enables fine control of morphology and structure but also saves energy and achieves zero emissions. To date, there have been no comparative studies on MnOx materials prepared using different Mn-MOFs precursors with this method. The objective of this study is to explore the effects of different Mn-MOFs precursors and oxidants on the structure, morphology, and catalytic efficiency of the synthesized MnOx materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation All chemical reagents were of analytical grade and did not require further purification for use in this work. We prepared four different Mn-based MOFs precursors. For Mn-MOF-74 [34], MnCl2·4H2O (5.55 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DOBDC, 1.68 mmol) were dissolved under stirring in a mixed solvent of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 45 mL), ethanol (3 mL), and deionized water (3 mL). The homogeneous solution was then transferred to a high-pressure hydrothermal reactor lined with polytetrafluoroethylene, sealed, and heated at 135 °C for 24 h. The yellow crystals were collected, washed with DMF, water, and ethanol, and dried for further use. For Mn-BTC and MnCe-BTC [32], MnCl2·4H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (total molar amount of 3.33 mmol), along with 3.1 mmol of benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), were dissolved in a 60 ml DMF solution. The mixed solution was sonicated for 30 min at room temperature. Then, the pale yellow solution was transferred to a high-pressure hydrothermal reactor lined with polytetrafluoroethylene, sealed, and heated at 130 °C for 24 h. The white samples were collected, washed three times with DMF and ethanol, and dried overnight at 80 °C. The Mn/Ce ratio in the MnCe-BTC sample was 4:1. For Mn-BDC [35], terephthalic acid (BDC, 12 mmol) and NaOH (24 mmol) were dissolved in 300 mL of deionized water to form a clear solution. Then, under stirring, 60 mL of MnSO4·H2O solution (0.25 M) was added dropwise to the solution. The mixed solution was further stirred at room temperature for 5 h. The resulting brown powder was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, then dried overnight at 80 °C to obtain Mn-BDC. MnOx catalysts were prepared using an alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method. Typically, a NaOH solution (0.05 M, 150 mL) was prepared. In the presence or absence of H2O2 (30 wt%, 10 mL), 0.5 g of Mn-based MOFs precursor was dispersed in the aforementioned NaOH solution and stirred overnight at room temperature. The mixture was filtered, washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried overnight at 80 °C to obtain brown (MnOx, MnCeOx) or black (MnO2) powder. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Rigaku Thermo Plus EVO2 thermogravimetric analyzer was utilized to obtain the thermal gravimetric (TG) curves of the prepared MnOx samples. The samples underwent heating from ambient temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under air atmospheres. The content of manganese and cerium in the samples was determined using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 720ES). The crystal structures of the prepared samples were examined using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima VI) over a scanning angle range of 5–80° at a scanning rate of 2° min−1. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the samples at 77 K were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 physical adsorption analyzer. The specific surface area was assessed using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The morphology and microstructure of all samples were analyzed utilizing a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Tescan Mira LMS) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Talos F200S). The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), and temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) of the catalysts were performed on a BelCata II instrument. Prior to the H2-TPR test, the catalyst was heated in nitrogen flow (50 ml min−1) at 150 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, it was heated in a 5 % H2/Ar mixture at a rate of 10 °C min−1 until reaching 800 °C. Prior to the NH3-TPD test, the catalysts were pre-treated in a helium flow (50 ml min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. The catalysts were then saturated with 10 % NH3/He gas for 1 h, followed by switching to helium flow for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed NH3 on the surface. Finally, the temperature was raised to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in helium flow, and the signal of desorbed gas (NH3, m/z = 16) was measured using an online mass spectrometer. Prior to the TPO test, the catalysts were pre-treated in a helium flow (50 ml min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. The catalysts were then saturated with 10 % O2/He gas for 1 h, followed by heating to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The signal of the outlet gas (CO2, m/z = 44) was measured using an online mass spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer. The binding energy of all spectra was calibrated with respect to the C1s (284.8 eV) peak internally. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activity tests were performed in a self-assembled temperature-programmed system. The prepared samples (100 mg, 40–60 mesh) were loaded into a quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor with continuous flow. The reaction gas consisted of a mixture of 50 ppm chlorobenzene (CB) and dry air, flowing at a rate of 20 ml min−1, equivalent to a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 12,000 ml g−1 h−1. The test temperature ranged from 100 °C to 300 °C. The concentration of CB was analyzed online by a gas chromatograph (GC, FL97Plus) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The CB conversion was calculated using the following equation: (1) CB conversion ( % ) = C C B , i n − C C B , o u t C C B , i n × 100 % where, the CCB,in and CCB,out represent the inlet and outlet CB concentrations detected before and after the reaction, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structure and morphology The MnOx material was synthesized by the alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method, as shown in Fig. 1 . The Mn-based MOF precursor was obtained by the solvothermal method using different organic ligands and the metal Mn or Mn/Ce (see Experimental section for details). Then, the MOF precursor was dispersed in an alkaline solution and etched to obtain the MnOx catalyst, using air or hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. We synthesized four different MOF precursors by varying the ligands, including BDC, DOBDC, and BTC, as well as doping with the metal Ce. The powder XRD patterns of the four MOF precursors are displayed in Fig. S1, exhibiting characteristic diffraction peaks consistent with literature reports [34–37], indicating the successful preparation of different MOF precursors. Subsequently, the MOF precursor was dispersed in a low-concentration alkaline solution for etching. As the Mn-based MOF precursors in basic medium could be very unstable, OH− ions entered the pores of the MOFs, attacking the metal centers. An ion-exchange reaction immediately occurred between the organic ligands and OH− ions to form intermediate Mn(OH)2 [34]. The reaction process is as follow: (1) Mnx(ligands) (s) + 2x OH− (aq.) → x Mn(OH)2 (s) + ligands2x− (aq.) Mn(OH)2 underwent facile in-situ oxidation by dissolved oxygen in the solution to form Mn3O4 [38,39] or deep-oxidized by strong oxidants to form MnO2 [40]. Due to the different coordination modes between the Mn and the various ligands, the stability of MOFs in the solution varied. For example, in Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BDC, Mn is 6-coordinated, with 5 oxygen atoms coming from the ligand and 1 oxygen atom from water molecules [41,42]. In Mn-BTC, the 6 oxygen atoms coordinated with Mn include 2 from the BTC ligand, 3 from the formate ligand, and 1 from water molecules. Additionally, the six MnO6 octahedra are interconnected through the carboxylate oxygen atoms of the formate ligands, forming a hexamer Mn6 cluster [43]. Moreover, the Ce in MnCe-BTC is 7-coordinated [44], with higher solution stability compared to Mn-BTC. Mn-MOF-74 displays a honeycomb-like one-dimensional pore structure characterized by a pore diameter of approximately 1.1 nm [34], and each Mn center is separated by DOBDC ligands along the pore direction. The pore size of Mn-BDC is slightly larger, measuring 0.95 nm × 1.79 nm [45]. In contrast, the pores in Mn-BTC are two-dimensional for water molecules [43]. Generally, the larger the dimension and size of the pores, the more favorable it is for molecular diffusion and OH− etching. Therefore, we speculate that the MnOx particles prepared from different MOF precursors may have the following size order: Mn-BTC > Mn-BDC > Mn-MOF-74. The XRD diffraction patterns of MnOx materials are illustrated in Fig. 2 . MnOx-74, MnOx-BTC, and MnOx-BDC, prepared from Mn-MOF-74, Mn-BTC, and Mn-BDC precursors, respectively, all exhibit characteristic peaks attributed to Mn3O4 (PDF # 75-1560), with MnOx-74 showing the weakest diffraction peak intensity. Based on the peak at 36.1° attributed to the (211) plane, the grain sizes of the MnOx samples are calculated to be 19.8 nm (MnOx-74), 29.6 nm (MnOx-BDC), and 31.5 nm (MnOx-BTC), consistent with our previous speculation. Additionally, MnOx-BTC also shows characteristic peaks attributed to MnO2 (PDF # 80-1098). Interestingly, the MnO2-74 sample, which was deeply oxidized in H2O2, only exhibits peaks attributed to MnO2. This further confirms our previous speculation that Mn-BTC is more susceptible to alkaline hydrolysis and can undergo partial deep oxidation even only in the presence of dissolved oxygen. The TG curves of MnOx-74 and MnO2-74 in air atmosphere were shown in Fig. S2. It can be seen that both of them have good thermal stability. The first slight weight loss between 50 °C to 300 °C mainly owed to the removal of adsorbed water on the surface of materials. As further heating continues, a weight loss at around 550 °C corresponded to the reduction of Mn3O4/MnO2 to Mn2O3. When the temperature rose to around 850 °C, the mass loss was due to oxygen release that occurred in the reduction of Mn2O3 to reform Mn3O4, which was consistent with that reported in the literature [34]. It is noteworthy to mention that MnCeOx-BTC derived from MnCe-BTC shows weak diffraction peaks attributed to Mn3O4 and mainly exhibits characteristic peaks of CeO2 (PDF # 34-0394), similar to the case of MnCeOx composite metal oxides prepared by pyrolysis in the literature [31,32]. This is likely due to the higher coordination number of Ce (7) compared to Mn (6), indicating that the bimetallic MnCe-BTC tends to form a more stable structure. As illustrated in Fig. 3 and Table S1, we used N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms to characterize the specific surface area and pore structure of Mn-MOF and MnOx materials. It is important to highlight that Mn-MOF exhibits relatively low N2 adsorption amount and BET surface area, while after alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation, MnOx materials show higher N2 adsorption amount and larger BET surface area. Significant hysteresis loops in the high relative pressure range (P/P0=0.8–1.0) can be observed for MnOx materials, demonstrating the presence of mesopores with a relatively concentrated pore size distribution after alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation. Among them, MnOx-74, MnOx-BTC, and MnOx-BDC all exhibit type H4 hysteresis loops, signifying the existence of slit-like pores formed through layered structures. In contrast, MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC exhibit type H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of slit-like pores created by agglomerated sheet-like particles. The BET surface area of MnOx materials ranges from 34 to 56 m2 g−1, while the pore volume varies from 0.20 to 0.29 cm3 g−1. Significantly higher BET surface area (209 m2 g−1) and pore volume (1.07 cm3 g−1) are exhibited by MnO2-74 in comparison to MnOx-74, with the pore size distribution also being more concentrated at 20.5 nm. Similarly, compared to MnOx-BTC, MnCeOx-BTC also shows a larger BET surface area (192 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.39 cm3 g−1), but the pore size distribution shifts to smaller pore size (8.2 nm), indicating that mesopores contribute most of the BET surface area and pore volume in MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC materials. From Fig. 3b, it can be observed that, in the mesoporous range, MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC exhibit relatively distinct and concentrated pore size distribution compared to MnOx-74, MnOx-BTC, and MnOx-BDC, which will be very conducive to the mass transfer, diffusion, and enrichment of low-concentration, high-throughput reactant molecules during the reaction process, thereby promoting the improvement of reaction activity [46]. SEM and TEM characterizations were utilized to examine the microstructure of the materials. As illustrated in Fig. 4 f–i, the Mn-MOF precursors, except for Mn-BDC, exhibit rod-like structures. Mn-MOF-74, Mn-BDC, and MnCe-BTC have smooth surfaces, while Mn-BTC shows the presence of spherical protrusions on its surface. After alkaline hydrolysis of the Mn-MOF precursors, the existence of hydrolysis-induced fractures can be observed (Fig. 4a, c inset). At the same time, Mn3O4 nanoparticles or curved MnO2 nanosheets are in-situ formed, creating irregular porous structures. In Fig. 4a, c, and e, square-shaped nanoparticles can be observed, mainly originating from the tetragonal-structure hausmannite Mn3O4. The particle size varies within the range of 20 to 30 nm, consistent with the crystallite size estimated by XRD. In MnO2-74, only nanosheets with a thickness of about 30 nm can be observed (Fig. 4b), indicating the formation of birnessite MnO2 through deep oxidation [47]. The slit pores formed by the aggregation of nanosheets afford MnO2-74 a substantial specific surface area and pore volume, in agreement with the N2 isotherms characterization results mentioned above. Interestingly, in MnOx-BTC, the presence of nanosheets is also observed (Fig. 4c), suggesting that Mn ions in MnOx-BTC may partially oxidized into MnO2, consistent with the findings of XRD characterization mentioned above. It is pertinent to highlight that MnCeOx-BTC exhibits a similar structure with coexistence of nanosheets and nanoparticles as in MnOx-BTC (Fig. 4d). Combining with the XRD characterization results, we speculate that the nanosheets in MnCeOx-BTC may be CeO2, and the nanoparticles may be Mn3O4. Meanwhile, the size of Mn3O4 nanoparticles in MnCeOx-BTC is significantly smaller than that in MnOx-BTC, demonstrating that the introduction of Ce significantly inhibits the deep oxidation of Mn and the growth and aggregation of Mn3O4 particles. Further insights into the microstructure of MnOx materials can be achieved from the TEM images presented in Figs. S3 and 5 . In MnOx-74 (Fig. S3a), MnOx-BTC (Fig. S3d), and MnOx-BDC (Fig. S3g), square-shaped nanocrystals belonging to Mn3O4 can be detected. The particle size of these nanocrystals also follows the sequence: MnOx-BTC > MnOx-BDC > MnOx-74, consistent with the estimation from XRD and SEM observations. The polycrystalline nature of Mn3O4 is definitively verified through the associated images from high-resolution TEM and the patterns of selected area electron diffraction (SAED). In MnOx-BTC and MnOx-BDC, due to their larger particle size and better crystallinity, diffraction rings attributed to the (220) crystal planes can be more clearly observed compared to MnOx-74. Consistent with SEM observations, MnOx-BTC also contains sheet-like structures of MnO2. However, in MnO2-74, all structures are formed by stacking sheet-like MnO2 particles, exhibiting a porous structure. The associated HR-TEM images and SAED patterns show only diffraction rings attributed to MnO2, indicating that Mn has been extensively oxidized. In the MnCeOx-BTC sample, a distinct polycrystalline structure with the coexistence of nanoparticles and nanosheets can be observed. Fig. S4 shows the SEM image of MnCeOx-BTC and corresponding element mappings. It can be seen that Mn and Ce are evenly distributed to form solid solution. Table S1 showed that the contents of Mn and Ce in the Mn-MOF precursors and MnOx materials. The content of Mn and Ce in MnCeOx-BTC materials was 27.3 wt% and 48.7 wt%. The diffraction patterns also reveal (101), (004) crystal planes belonging to Mn3O4 and (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes belonging to CeO2. This indicates that the introduction of Ce not only suppresses the deep oxidation and growth of Mn3O4 particles but also exposes different crystal planes. It also can be seen that in Fig. S4 both C and Cl are randomly distributed in MnCeOx-BTC. The chlorine mainly come from MnCl2·4H2O in the precursor, and traces amount of C might come from contamination during SEM characterization. 3.2 The influence of MOFs precursors and oxidant The reducibility of the materials was assessed using H2-TPR experiments. In Fig. 6 a, the H2-TPR curves of various MnOx samples are presented. The reduction peaks within the temperature range of 200–300 °C can be linked to the conversion from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, whereas the peaks at about 430 °C are associated with the transition from Mn3O4 to MnO [48–51]. The reduction peak at approximately 550 °C corresponds to the reduction of lattice oxygen on the surface [52]. It can be observed that MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC samples exhibit lower temperatures for the reduction from Mn3O4 to MnO compared to the other samples, indicating that they may possess better low-temperature reducibility. Furthermore, in the MnCeOx-BTC sample, additional reduction peaks at 623 °C, attributed to the transition from Ce4+ to Ce3+ [32], and at 193 °C, associated with the reduction of surface active oxygen [52], are observed. The surface reducibility of the materials is directly linked to their catalytic efficiency, where lower reduction temperatures generally indicate higher catalytic activity. Additionally, a higher hydrogen consumption implies better reducibility. Therefore, we quantitatively studied the total H2 consumption during the reduction process (100–700 °C) for different materials (Table S2). Although MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC samples exhibit relatively lower hydrogen consumption among the studied samples, not all oxygen participates in the redox reactions. The oxygen easily to be reduced at lower temperatures (<450 °C) is more directly related to the catalytic activity [37,52]. The catalytic oxidation of chlorinated VOCs relies significantly on the surface acidity of the catalyst. Acidic sites on the catalyst surface play a crucial role in breaking the C-Cl bond present in chlorinated VOCs. Hence, enhancing the quantity of acidic sites on the catalyst surface can aid in effectively eliminating active chlorine. The assessment of surface acidity in the MnOx samples was conducted through NH3-TPD analysis, and the outcomes are depicted in Fig. 6b and Table S2. These acidic sites are usually classified as weak (<200 °C), moderate (200 °C–400 °C), and strong (>400 °C) based on their temperature ranges [53]. Among them, the moderate acidic sites play a more significant role in the reaction. From Fig. 6b, it can be observed that all MnOx samples, except MnOx-BDC, possess three types of acidic sites. Among them, MnO2-74 has the highest proportion of moderate acidic sites and the largest amount of desorbed NH3, which will facilitate the dissociation of chlorine, thereby promoting the enhancement of reaction activity in the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene. For a more in-depth understanding of the surface chemical composition of these materials, we conducted XPS analysis. Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectra and valence state calculation results of Mn 2p, Ce 3d, and O 1s for different materials. The Mn 2p spectra of different MnOx materials are shown in Fig. 7a, revealing two different splitting orbitals ascribed to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2. For the Mn 2p3/2 peak, it can be deconvoluted into Mn2+, Mn3+, Mn4+ and a satellite peak [54], located at binding energies of 640.5, 641.8, 643.6, and 646.1 eV, respectively. The satellite peak is typically attributed to collisions of valence electrons with excited electrons from the transition metal oxide. This satellite peak is a typical Mn2+ excitation peak [55]. The presence of both Mn3+ and Mn4+ indicates that Mn exists in a composite valence state across all materials, with Mn3+ possibly arising from oxygen vacancies formed due to crystal defects. Mn3+ demonstrates enhanced reducibility, thereby facilitating electron transfer and catalytic reaction cycles [56]. The Mn3+/Mn4+ molar ratios, computed from the peak areas, are presented in Fig. 7d, and they follow the following order: MnOx-74 (3.51) > MnOx-BDC (3.42) > MnOx-BTC (3.12), which is in direct contrast to the order in the grain size mentioned earlier. Furthermore, the ratios for MnO2-74 (4.63) and MnCeOx-BTC (4.43) materials notably surpass those of the other materials. This indicates that grain size, deep oxidation, and metal doping all influence the distribution of Mn3+ on the material's surface. More Mn3+ on the catalyst surface implies better reducibility and better adsorption and activation of oxygen, which in turn enhances the catalytic performance and oxygen activation capability [57,58]. Fig. 7b displays the Ce 3d spectra of the MnCeOx-BTC sample, including two different split orbitals for Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, represented by U and V, respectively. The peak positions at 900.5, 903.0, 907.0, 916.3, 882.0, 885.1, 888.5, and 898.0 eV correspond to the split peaks U, U', U'', U''', V, V', V'', and V''', respectively [59,60]. The U' and V' peaks are ascribed to Ce3+ species, the existence of which leads to charge imbalance, forming unsaturated chemical bonds and oxygen vacancies [61]. The remaining six peaks are assigned to Ce4+, indicating that lattice oxygen in the catalyst can store and transfer between Ce3+ and Ce4+ species [62,63]. The molar ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ in the MnCeOx-BTC sample is 0.26, higher than that reported in literature for manganese-cerium composite metal oxides [31,32,37], suggesting that its surface is more prone to the creation of oxygen vacancies, thereby promoting catalytic reactions. Regarding the O1s spectra, there are two distinct peaks located at 531.5 and 529.2 eV, representing adsorbed oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olatt), respectively [37,64,65]. Fig. 7d reveals that the Oads/Olatt ratio of MnO2-74 (1.39) and MnCeOx-BTC (1.77) is higher than that of other MnOx catalysts. This trend is similar to the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio we discussed earlier. This is mainly because MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC have a lower degree of crystallization, with higher Mn3+ content, resulting in many oxygen vacancies across the surfaces, leading to a higher amount of adsorbed oxygen [49,66,67]. However, in the catalytic oxidation of chlorinated VOCs on transition metal oxides, the process typically adheres to the Mars–Van–Krevelen reaction mechanism. This mechanism underscores the importance of lattice oxygen in facilitating the activation and cleavage of C-H bonds [68]. Therefore, achieving an equilibrium between adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen content is more favorable for this reaction to proceed. 3.3 Catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene Chlorobenzene (CB) was chosen as the model molecule to investigate the catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts. The catalytic activity curves of different MnOx catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 a, with the associated T50 and T90 values listed in Table S2. With the exception of MnOx-BTC, all catalysts were able to completely convert CB within the investigated temperature range. Although MnO2-74 and MnOx-74, MnOx-BDC and MnCeOx-BTC showed the same complete conversion temperature for CB, the T90 values of the catalysts followed the following order: MnO2-74 (174 °C) < MnOx-74 (176 °C) < MnOx-BDC (191 °C) < MnCeOx-BTC (192 °C) < MnOx-BTC (197 °C). MnO2-74 and MnCeOx-BTC exhibited decreased T50 and T90 values compared to MnOx-74 and MnOx-BTC, respectively, indicating that deep oxidation and metal doping indeed enhance the catalyst's activity. Among them, MnO2-74 exhibited the most notable catalytic efficiency, achieving 50 % and 90 % CB conversion at reaction temperatures of 148 °C and 174 °C, correspondingly. The outstanding catalytic activity of MnO2-74 can be ascribed to its substantial specific surface area and pore volume, high Mn3+ content, better surface reducibility, and sufficient acidic sites, as deduced from the above characterization analysis. A substantial specific surface area and appropriate pore size facilitate the adsorption, mass transfer, and enrichment of CB molecules, while sufficient acidic sites promote CB adsorption and dechlorination. Additionally, the high Mn3+ content and better surface reducibility facilitate the oxidative decomposition of CB. Table S3 lists Mn-based catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of CB documented in the literature. From the table, it can be observed that compared to other catalysts, the MnO2-74 catalyst is highly effective for the catalytic oxidation of low-concentration, high-throughput CB. The determination of apparent activation energy (E a), as obtainable from Arrhenius plots, is used to reflect the level of difficulty in catalytic reactions. It is generally believed that the oxidation of CB conforms to a first-order kinetic equation [31]. As illustrated in Fig. 8b, the E a values for the MnOx catalysts are ranked as follows: MnO2-74 (15.6 kJ mol−1) < MnOx-74 (18.2 kJ mol−1) < MnOx-BDC (22.1 kJ mol−1) < MnCeOx-BTC (25.5 kJ mol−1) < MnOx-BTC (29.5 kJ mol−1). Among them, MnO2-74 catalyst possesses the lowest E a value, indicating that CB molecules are more easily converted on MnO2-74. In addition, the TOF is one of the most commonly used parameters to describe the catalytic activity, which can provide a clear means to compare the activities of catalysts. The TOF values of the catalysts were calculated at 120 °C based on surface active oxygen, as shown in Table S2. The TOF values of MnOx catalysts are arranged as follows: MnO2-74 (5.89 × 10−4 s−1) > MnOx-74 (4.51 × 10−4 s−1) > MnOx-BDC (2.90 × 10−4 s−1) > MnCeOx-BTC (1.26 × 10−4 s−1) > MnOx-BTC (7.18 × 10−5 s−1), which were consistent with the E a values. The MnO2-74 catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity to CB oxidation reaction. Therefore, we selected the MnO2-74 catalyst to investigate its catalytic stability in the CB oxidation. It is widely acknowledged that in the catalytic oxidation of chlorinated VOCs, catalysts often experience a decrease in activity due to chlorine poisoning. Fig. 8c shows the conversion of CB over time at 200 °C and 300 °C for the MnO2-74 catalyst. At 200 °C, the conversion of CB by the MnO2-74 catalyst rapidly decreases from 100 % to 35 % within 3 h. It has been reported that oxychlorination reaction occurred on the transition metal oxides would lead to the generation of chlorinated hydrocarbons and polychlorinated compounds, which can deactivate the catalyst [69]. In contrast, with the elevation of the reaction temperature to 300 °C, the catalyst's activity slowly decreases from 100 % to 56 % within the first 10 h and shows no significant deactivation during the subsequent 70 h of continuous reaction. This is because at higher temperatures, the Deacon reaction can eliminate chlorinated species (e.g. HCl) on the catalyst's surface, preventing catalyst poisoning [70]. 3.4 Deactivation mechanism To investigate the catalyst deactivation mechanism, XRD, TEM, XPS and TPO characterization were performed on the MnO2-74 catalyst used at 200 °C and 300 °C. The XRD patterns and TEM images of MnO2-74 before and after catalytic reaction were displayed in Figs. S6 and S7. The XRD pattern and nanosheet structure remained unchanged, indicating that prolonged catalytic reaction did not alter the catalyst's crystal structure and microstructure. According to the fitting results in Fig. S5a and the calculated results in Fig. S5d, the Mn3+/Mn4+ molar ratio of the MnO2-74 catalyst decreased from 4.63 to 4.24 at 200 °C and 3.71 at 300 °C, correspondingly, demonstrating that the high-temperature catalytic reaction led to the oxidation of Mn3+ and a decrease in the catalyst's surface reducibility. Worth mentioning, as shown in Fig. S5c and calculated results in Fig. S5d, the Oads/Olatt ratio increased from 1.39 to 2.48 subsequent to the stability test at 200 °C, indicating that the catalytic process promoted the generation of active surface oxygen. However, after the stability test at 300 °C for 70 h, the Oads/Olatt ratio decreased to 1.25. Literatures suggest that the Deacon reaction and oxychlorination reactions are prone to occur on metal oxides, consuming active oxygen and generating chlorinated hydrocarbons, which can cause catalyst poisoning [69]. To investigate the possible deactivation mechanism of the catalyst, we compared the Cl 2p spectra of the fresh MnO2-74 catalyst and after the stability tests (Fig. S5b). The relative chlorine content on the surfaces of MnO2-74, MnO2-74-200 °C, and MnO2-74-300 °C was found to be 0.00 %, 6.74 %, and 3.60 %, respectively. The fresh MnO2-74 did not contain chlorine, but the surface chlorine content significantly increased after the stability test at 200 °C, signifying the generation of chlorine species on the catalyst surface. However, after a long-term reaction at 300 °C, the amount of chlorine species on the surface did not reach the same level as that on MnO2-74-200 °C. The Cl 2p1/2 spectra in Fig. S5b can be resolved into two distinct peaks corresponding to organic chlorine (Clorg) and inorganic chlorine (Clin). The peak located at a binding energy of 199.8 eV belongs to organic chlorine, and the peak at 198.3 eV belongs to inorganic chlorine [71,72]. The Clin/Clorg ratio reflects the relative content of inorganic and organic chlorine on the catalyst surface. The Clin/Clorg ratio for the MnO2-74-200 °C catalyst was 1.57, indicating the accumulation of chlorine species, which may be MnClx or MnOyClz, blocking and occupying active sites, limiting the adsorption and activation of CB and oxygen molecules, thus decreasing the catalytic activity [12,13]. Upon elevating the reaction temperature to 300 °C, the Clin/Clorg ratio decreased to 1.27, indicating that the temperature increase can remove some inorganic chlorine through the Deacon reaction [73]. The removal of inorganic chlorine generated vacant sites that can activate oxygen to produce new surface active oxygen, thus continuing to participate in the oxidation of CB. Fig. 8d displays the mass spectrometry signal of CO2 from the TPO tests of the two catalysts after the stability tests, and Table S2 summarizes the corresponding oxygen consumption. The TPO curves of the used MnO2-74-200 °C catalyst showed the strongest CO2 signal peaks at 534 °C and 672 °C. Similarly, the TPO curves of the used MnO2-74-300 °C catalyst showed CO2 signal peaks at 467 °C and 638 °C, mainly attributed to carbon deposition on the catalyst surface [74]. The oxygen consumption of the used MnO2-74-200 °C catalyst (0.59 mmol g−1) was notably greater in comparison to that of the used MnO2-74-300 °C catalyst (0.13 mmol g−1), demonstrating a considerably greater surface carbon deposition on the MnO2-74-200 °C catalyst as opposed to the MnO2-74-300 °C catalyst. Literatures suggest that excessive acidic sites may lead to carbon deposition on the catalyst surface [75]. The combined effect of carbon deposition and chlorine poisoning ultimately led to the rapid deactivation of the MnO2-74 catalyst at 200 °C. 4 Conclusion To sum up, we have provided a straightforward and efficient technique for the high-throughput preparation of MnOx materials, allowing control over their morphology and microstructure. Using different Mn-based MOFs as precursors with the presence of an oxidant in an alkaline hydrolysis treatment, MnOx materials with various shapes and structures are in-situ synthesized. The Mn-based MOFs undergo ion exchange with OH− to form manganese hydroxide, which is then rapidly in-situ oxidized by dissolved oxygen or hydrogen peroxide to form either Mn3O4 nanoparticles or MnO2 nanosheets. This alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method not only allows for fine control of morphology and structure but also saves energy compared to traditional MOFs pyrolysis methods, making it a zero-emission process. Characterization and experimental results indicate that the solution stability of MOFs precursors, oxidants, and metal doping all have significant effects on the structure and catalytic efficiency of the catalysts. Among all the MnOx materials investigated, MnO2-74 exhibits excellent catalytic activity (T90 = 174 °C) and the lowest apparent activation energy for the reaction (Ea = 15.6 kJ mol−1). This is mainly attributed to its large surface area and mesoporous structure, better reducibility at lower temperatures, sufficient acidic sites, and enhanced oxygen activation ability. Catalytic stability tests reveal that surface carbon and inorganic chlorine may occupy catalytic sites and lead to catalyst deactivation. coredata.dc:description: In this research, we introduce a simple, effective, and eco-friendly approach for preparing MnOx materials with a hierarchical porous structure and apply it to the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzene. In this method, different Mn-based MOFs are used as templates, and MnOx materials with various morphologies and structures are prepared through an alkaline hydrolysis-oxidation method. Different Mn-MOF precursors, oxidants and doping of different metals have a considerable influence on the structural morphology of the obtained MnOx materials. Through adjusting the structural morphology, it is conducive to transfer, diffusion and enrichment of chlorobenzene during the reaction process, and improving the reaction activity. MnO2-74 catalyst derived from Mn-MOF-74 in the presence of H2O2 showed the best catalytic activity (T90 = 174 °C). The exceptional catalytic efficiency is attributed to its large specific surface area, mesoporous structure, better low-temperature reducibility, sufficient acidic sites, and enhanced oxygen activation ability. The primary cause of the decrease in catalytic activity is the existence of surface carbon and inorganic chlorine on the catalyst. This green, efficient, and economical preparation method introduces a novel strategy for the traditional derivatization of MOFs to prepare metal oxide materials for the catalytic oxidation of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs).
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient MnOx catalysts derived from Mn-MOFs for chlorobenzene oxidation: The influence of MOFs precursors, oxidant and doping of Ce metal
